syllabus:
**Objectives****:** This course is designed to support college freshmen in their use of English language in academic context and to improve their reading proficiency and vocabulary knowledge through intensive and extensive reading and reading skill/strategy training. In addition to reading and vocabulary abilities, this class also aims to build up students’ proficiency in the other three main language skills—writing, listening, and speaking—through activities that integrate the four language skills. The objectives of this class include developing students’ (1) effective English reading skills, (2) fluency in expressing ideas in oral and written forms in English, and (3) self-study skills using technologies such as computers and internet.

In order to do so, there a four-pronged approach to the course:

1) Firstly, the course textbook and online practice website emphasize vocabulary learning and building in order to provide students the structure and tools to acquire new words. There is also a purposefully structured skills and strategies program to propel language learning and create independent learners. Furthermore, the textbook helps improve reading proficiency and develop practical critical thinking.

2) Secondly, over the course of the first-half of the semester, students will undertake one major task-based project, in which task groups, of no more than 4 students per group, are asked to investigate areas and topics that are of interest to them, and then present their work to the class via film, audio, performance or presentation. Examples include short films (comedy, drama, horror), radio shows (news, weather, interviews, ads), plays (skits, drama, musicals), shows (music, magic, games), or interesting topical presentations on topics that are of serious interest to themselves.

3) You must visit Self-Access Room (Main campus 樸101) and/or English Chat Room (Gongguan Library A107 or Main Campus 樸102) as much as you can. You are expected to visit them for at least _10 hours_ in total this semester.

4) Finally, students will be asked to do a writing workshop in the second half of the course, by writing up short critical essays based on the readings that have been done in class.

N.B: All elements to the course will be evaluated and assessed when calculating the final grade.

**Textbook**:

Daise, D., Norloff, C., & Carne, P. (2015). _Q: Skills for Success: Reading and Writing, 4._ Second Edition. New York: Oxford University Press.

Guidelines and Requirements: The Ten Commandments!

1.  Punctual attendance is essential and being on time is polite. Talk to or email me if you can’t attend class. 3 strikes and you’re out!
2.  This is a Flip Class. Homework must be done for the class to work properly. This includes reviewing and previewing class chapters.
3.  Actively participate in class discussions.
4.  Grades will be downgraded for failure to attend class without reason, excessive lateness, lack of participation or failure to do homework. 
5.  You need to submit homework _six times_ during the semester.
6.  Task assignments, homework, and paragraph essays must be done and be on time.
7.  Smartphones, tablets, etc, must be turned off unless needed in class.
8.  No eating during class, but drinks are allowed.
9.  ou must visit Self-Access Room (Main campus 樸101) and/or English Chat Room (Gongguan Library A107 or Main Campus 樸102) as much as you can. You are expected to visit them for at least _10 hours_ in total this semester.
10.   Optional English Practice: Students should practice their English every chance they get. Any English-language encounters can be recorded in your Class Journal for extra grade!

Grading Policy: The Business!

Final Grades are based and assessed on student performances in the following areas:

1) Attendance/Participation/Homework: 10%

2) Task Project: 20% (Presentation: 10%, drafts and reflection: 10%)

3) Midterm Quiz: 10%

4) Critical Essays/Movie review (x3): 25%

5) Self-access chat room/e portfolio: 10%

6) Final Exam: 25%
